The status quo strongly favors no human cases - most novel coronaviruses never infect humans, and those that do typically require specific receptor compatibility and sustained contact opportunities. For my forecast to move higher, I would need evidence of: (1) active human surveillance detecting early cases, (2) known high-risk exposures already under investigation, or (3) laboratory work with the virus being conducted at scale. For it to move lower, I would need confirmation that the virus has inherent biological barriers to human infection or that all samples are under stringent biosafety protocols. The combination of the very short remaining timeframe and low historical base rates drives this probability down significantly, though I maintain a small non-zero probability given that spillover events, while rare, can occur unpredictably.
